Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: A New Approach to Discovery and Learning in Management Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
The continual success of an individual in today's global economy depends on the adequacy of knowledge and skills learned during both academic and professional experience. Although technological enhancements vault businesses forward ever faster, similar use of technology in higher education has been slow to keep pace with business environment. Lecture-based learning and the case-method are still the dominant forms of instruction in the world's leading institutions. To adequately meet the needs of an innovative economy, students and professors need to harness the power of interactive-learning with technology to drive engagement, discovery, and knowledge retention. Gaming presents a unique approach to facilitating a new type of interaction among students if focused on the right academic subjects. Gamification provides an environment for enhanced competition, accountability, discovery and instant feedback, which improve overall learning outcomes above traditional lecture-based methods. The games will supplement current teaching methods across academic fields and benefit both knowledge seekers and knowledge providers.

This team will develop a scientific approach for 'gamification' in higher education, and to facilitate the discovery of knowledge through action-based learning. The team will design and create games covering core skills taught in business schools, starting with core disciplines, such as Operations Management, Marketing, and Finance, and eventually expand into other academic fields. The design principles will closely follow the scientific approach used to design the Forecast Sharing Game (FSG) previously created by the team PI as a means to collect field data. This I-Corps team proposes to design a portfolio of games encompassing fundamental management concepts, while learning, researching, discovering, and documenting pedagogical scientific principles required to make such games effective learning tools. The team intends to accomplish this in three stages: individual game design and build, creation of a centralized technology platform, and development of a game publishing mechanism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The I-Corps project for “A New Approach to Discovery and Learning in Management Education” sought to understand the commercial potential for gamification of fundamental concepts taught in business school. First, we investigated the types of digital learning tools used in classrooms. Second, we categorized the challenges to using games of any type in higher education. Third, we captured characteristics of games in order to be successful teaching and action-based, role-playing learning tools in classrooms. Finally, we applied the lessons of the I-Corps program, and in particular those related to construction of a Business Model Canvas, to determine the viability of a commercialization strategy for building games based on fundamental concepts taught in business schools.

The broader impact of the project is to facilitate more widespread use of games and gamification as effective interactive learning tools by professors who wish to use them. Start-ups, for-profit and non-for-profit organizations all need capable managers who can make effective decisions in the face of complexity and uncertainty. As a society, we observe and document many catastrophic economic and corporate failures due to, for example, a lack of understanding risks and risk management – a fundamental concept taught during business education. Of the utmost importance for our society, therefore, is to educate the next generation; equip them with relevant frameworks/tools that go beyond simple imaginary narratives but instead ensure students truly internalize and understand the fundamental academic concepts taught. Our team believes experiential learning is the key to achieving this goal, and that interactive, educational games will play a crucial role in this teaching approach.  We seek to enable both producers of games and consumers of games that share this vision. Small business growth in the education industry is made possible by providing a means for game authors to easily build and distribute games. On the other side of the market, professors must be enabled to easily bring games into classrooms that reinforce theory and case-based lectures with hands-on discovery of knowledge through an action-learning experience. The instant visualization of game results allows professors to tailor teaching approaches and validate subject mastery of students.  By helping professors to supplement traditional teaching methods with a successful game-based learning experience, we believe students will more effectively retain and apply management knowledge in the real world.  Hence the project has the potential to both grow and empower the workforce to be more efficient, more productive and more innovative, thus driving economic growth in the U.S.

We determined a viable and potentially business to commercialize based on our technology of gamification. The path to commercialization was based upon the development of a Business Model Canvas indicating a viable business opportunity when subjected to close scrutiny by the I-Corps instructors. We have since decided to pursue this idea in full. The EL on the project has dedicated himself full time to the commercialization efforts. The team is raising capital to bring the innovation to market, and deliberately using the results of the I-Corps program to justify, inform and promote progress with investors.
